intro: Tithymalus gayi, commonly known as the New Zealand flax, is a flowering plant native to New Zealand. It belongs to the family Polygonaceae and is characterized by its tall, erect stems and clusters of small, greenish-white flowers. The plant is often found in coastal and lowland areas, thriving in well-drained soils. Its leaves are long and narrow, often used traditionally by Māori for weaving purposes. Tithymalus gayi plays an important ecological role in its native habitat, supporting various insect and bird species.
